http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the English language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The English is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.
A document of a specific kind (e.g. normative documents, legal documents, etc.) published by the United Nations for certain reasons.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the Arabic language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The Arabic is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the Chinise language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The Chinese is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.
A concept that is related somehow to a term (e.g. because it represents the meaning of a particular term).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the Spanish language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The Spanish is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.
A particular version of United Nation document written according to a certain language, chosen from the six official United Nation languages.

The United Nations Document Ontology (UNDO) is an OWL 2 DL ontology that aims at providing a framework for the description of all entities and the relations that are explicitly or implicitly introduced within United Nations documents (normative documents, legal documents, etc.).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the Russian language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The Russian is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.

Something that allows one to link a proponent entity to a receiver entity according to a specific semantics - e.g. saying that a document (proponent) cites (semantics) another document (receiver), or that an organization (proponent) approves (semantics) a certain document (receiver), etc.
The receiver entity of a relation.
A particular kind of United Nation document that contains a formal expression of the will of a principal or subsidiary organ or other empowered bodies.
A particular language officially adopted by the United Nation for publishing their documents (Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian, Spanish).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: This entity representing the French language has been originally defined in the Library of Congress concept scheme (skos:ConceptScheme) available at http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/iso639-1, which maps all the two-letters codes for languages introduced in the specification ISO 639-1 as Linked Open Data.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: The French is one of the six official languages used for publishing United Nations documents.
The proponent entity of a relation.
A mechanism that allows someone to link a specific entity (e.g. a relation) to a target document (or its parts), with the intent of specifying from where that entity has been actually derived from.
